author: https://orcid.org/0000-0002-8083-6048
text: Since it is a legal issue, wouldn't https://w3id.org/linkflows/superpattern/latest/alwaysQualifier work better?
resp_text: Thank you for your review! While we agree that when it comes to legal issues a more concrete language should be used, our formalisation is of a statement which expresses an opinion rather than a legal fact. Licenses with a non-commercial clause do not inhibit reuse of biodiversity data because of legal reasons but as a consequence of the difficulty to reuse data.

author: https://orcid.org/0000-0002-8083-6048
text: I learned a lot from this formalization. In particular, about nesting object classes.

author: https://orcid.org/0000-0002-8083-6048
text: The provided label for the superpattern instance refers to 'licenses with a non-commertial clause' in general, whereas the actual formalization has the specific kind of license 'Creative Commons NonCommercial' in subject position. This should be make consistent in one way or the other.
resp_text: We agree with this review comment and have addressed it by defining a new class license-with-non-commercial-clause which is a subclass of software license (Q79719) and is related to Q65071627 and have used this new class as the subject of our updated formalisation.

author: https://orcid.org/0000-0002-8083-6048
text: I am a bit uncertain about the subject class. It is defined as a subclass of 'knowledge graph' but seems to be treated more like an instance. I think it would be good to better specify (in the formalization nanopub or the class definition one) what the instances of the class 'OpenBiodiv knowledge graph' really are (maybe the different versions/branches?).
resp_text: I agree that it was not clear that this is an instance. To address this review comment, I have created a new class (latest-release-of-openbiodiv), which is a subclass of software release (Q20631656) and related to openbiodiv-knowledge-graph, and I have updated the formalisation nanopub to say that 'The latest release of the OpenBiodiv knowledge graph contains semantic triples extracted from biodiversity literature'. Thank you for your review!

author: https://orcid.org/0000-0002-8083-6048
text: The provenance of the formalization is the result of a "FormalizationAcitvity", which is correctly chosen and filled in.

author: https://orcid.org/0000-0002-8083-6048
text: The provenance of the formalization is a "FormalizationActivity" as was correctly chosen and filled in.

author: https://orcid.org/0000-0002-8083-6048
text: The provenance indicates that this is a joint-authored formalization.

author: https://orcid.org/0000-0002-8083-6048
text: The rephrasing of the scientific claim is clear and in an AIDA-form.

author: https://orcid.org/0000-0002-8083-6048
text: The modeling of the formalization reflects very well the scientific claim.

author: https://orcid.org/0000-0002-8083-6048
text: The modeling of the formalization reflects very well the scientific claim.

author: https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0191-7211
text: As humans typically belong to many different groups of different kinds, I am inclined to think that the context class should more specifically be 'social group of humans' (possibly with a quite technical and precise definition) and not just 'group of humans'.
resp_text: Indeed https://www.wikidata.org/wiki/Q874405 (social group) matches better than https://www.wikidata.org/wiki/Q16334295 (group of humans) and thus was replaced.

author: https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0191-7211
text: I am wondering whether the "never causes" is a bit too strong a relation, also given the natural language sentence. "Never affects" might be more precise than "never causes". (This is also a stronger statement, more likely to be wrong, but that's not necessarily a bad thing.)
resp_text: I do have to agree. However, I changed it to affects instead of causes since it is a negation and leaves the option open to find a positive correlation in the future.

author: https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0191-7211
text: while this class nanopub is a subclass of size from wikipedia, it doesn't make a formal relation to the neocortex (e.g. that it specifically an attribute of the neocortex). thus, the class formalization could be improved.
resp_text: Thank you for the review. It has been changed in the formal definition of class which is now skos:related to both - the cortex class and the size class in Wikidata.

author: https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0191-7211
text: The provenance of the formalization needs to be a "FormalizationActivity", but at the moment the "sub:quote" field is missing. There a link to the article from which the scientific claim was taken needs to be specified ("sub:quote prov:wasQuotedFrom <https://royalsocietypublishing.org/doi/10.1098/rsbl.2021.0158>"), together with the quote from the article from which the scientific claim was derived ("sub:quote prov:value "add phrase from original article from which the scientific claim was extracted or rephrased" ").
resp_text: The missing information have been added.

author: https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0191-7211
text: The modelling of the formalization seems to reflect well the content of the scientific claim.

author: https://orcid.org/0000-0003-2310-3013
text: The provenance part should be using the template 'generated from a formalization activity'.
resp_text: Provenance changed to show generated by a formalization activity.

author: https://orcid.org/0000-0003-2310-3013
text: The provenance of this formalization is a "FormalizationActivity" where the link to the article and the actual quote from the same article from which the scientific claim was derived need to be specified together with the orcid of the formalization author. This should be changed accordingly.
resp_text: Provenance was changed to show that it was generated by a formalization activity, and the necessary attributes of that template were added.

author: https://orcid.org/0000-0003-2310-3013
text: Something small: I would start the scientific claim with an upper case and end it with a period.

author: https://orcid.org/0000-0003-0169-8159
text: The provenance should use the 'Generated by a formalization activity' template.
resp_text: I agree and I changed the provenance using the 'Generated by a formalization activity' template following reviewer's suggestion.

author: https://orcid.org/0000-0003-0169-8159
text: I feel that the context class of 'clinical entity' doesn't add anything. It's a very general class. Just leaving it empty (= universal class) might make more sense.
resp_text: I changed the context with the more specific class 'genetic disorder' that is stated in the assertion but was not included in the first version, which is 'autosomal recessive disorder' thus declaring the congenital characteristic of this disorder.

author: https://orcid.org/0000-0003-0169-8159
text: You are now stating that the given deficiency is caused by the ERAD pathway, which doesn't sound right. I suppose it should be something like: it is caused by the dysfunction of the ERAD pathway. So, it would mean to mint a new class 'dysfunction of ERAD pathway' and then use this class in object position.
resp_text: I adressed the good point made by the reviewer following his suggestion: mint a new class 'dysfunction of ERAD pathway' and then use this class in object position.

author: https://orcid.org/0000-0003-0169-8159
text: The provenance of this formalization should be a "FormalizationActivity". As such, the source of the scientific claim (the original scientific article) can be specified, together with the quote from the article that contains the scientific claim and the orcid of the author of the formalization.
resp_text: I agree and I changed the provenance using the 'Generated by a formalization activity' template accordingly.

author: https://orcid.org/0000-0003-0169-8159
text: I think the object class needs to be "autosomal-recessive-disorder-of-ERAD-pathway" instead of just the "ERAD-pathway".
resp_text: I agree that the object 'ERAD pathway' is not the appropiate. I addressed this minting a new class 'dysfunction of ERAD pathway' which is more accurate.

author: https://orcid.org/0000-0003-0169-8159
text: I believe the formalization structure is good, reflecting almost all the details of the scientific claim. If the missing details about the "autosomal recessive disorder" were to be included, this would make the formalization complete in my view.
resp_text: "autosomal recessive disorder" has been added as "genetic disorder" to declare the context of the assertion

author: https://orcid.org/0000-0001-9079-039X
text: The usage of dx.doi.org type of DOIs has been deprecated. Instead, the author should use doi.org such as https://doi.org/10.1007%2F978-3-030-71903-6_32 .
resp_text: Changed to the suggested doi. Thank you

author: https://orcid.org/0000-0001-9079-039X

resp_text: Indeed, I misunderstood the quote part. The quote now comes from (the abstract of) the original article

resp_text: I updated the quote, that now comes from the (abstract of the) original article.

author: https://orcid.org/0000-0001-9079-039X
text: I was wondering if a better context class would be "Digital Humanities research", instead of just "Digital Humanities".
resp_text:
I agree that this can be confusing. In response to a formalization review comment (3), I added a new class 
"Digital humanities research"which is a subclass of the resource "research" in wikidata and related to the resource "digital humanities" in wikidata.

resp_text: Thanks, I updated the object slot to http://purl.org/np/RAiUYY1dbEDbcsscapEmbMMHsgJmjEJ1yUoNsxZIH1r90#transcription-of-stmn2

author: https://orcid.org/0000-0001-6501-0806
text: The provenance, which is a "FormalizationActivity" should also include the actual quote from the article from which the scientific claim was derived. As such, the "sub:quote prov:value <quote_from_article_from_which_the_scientific_claim_was_derived>" and "prov:wasQuotedFrom <http://doi.org/10.1038/ng.3130>" should be added.

author: https://orcid.org/0000-0001-6501-0806
text: Maybe the use of a causal relation like "contributes to" can also be used here.
resp_text: I don't think the original publication shows a causal relationship. It seems to me only a correlation is proven.

author: https://orcid.org/0000-0001-6501-0806
text: Something small: starting the sentence containing the scientific claim of the super-pattern with a capital letter.

author: https://orcid.org/0000-0001-8004-0464
text: I think the label of the superpattern instance, in particular the 'essential regulator' part, is a bit stronger than what the superpattern is actually expressing. I suggest to revise the label a bit such that it better reflects what the formalization says.
resp_text: I believe the label in itself represents the meaning of the original article, but the qualifier wasn't the suitable one to express it. I have modified the qualifier from "generally" to "mostly" to specify that the original article claims that Shh is an essential regulator.

author: https://orcid.org/0000-0001-8004-0464
text: The quote provided in the provenance seems to be a general quote from the source rather than the specific passage on which this formalization is based.
resp_text: The original quote from the article has been replaced with a more specific one

text: The modelling of the formalization is very good.

author: https://orcid.org/0000-0001-8004-0464

author: https://orcid.org/0000-0003-2432-4125
text: This formalisation paper captures excellently one of the main claims made in the original article. I have a small comment regarding the style of the formalisation paper itself. There is no quote from the original paper and instead the paraphrased claim was inserted (sub:quote triple in the Provenance section).
resp_text: an exact quote from the article was added

author: https://orcid.org/0000-0003-2432-4125

author: https://orcid.org/0000-0003-2432-4125

author: https://orcid.org/0000-0003-2432-4125
text: The scientific claim does not seem to be atomic, as it mentions two genes, IRX3 and IRX5. I think it should be broken into two different claims, one for each of these genes.
resp_text: The paper refers to both genes and both genes are regulated. Not sure if it should be split into two claims or remain as one

author: https://orcid.org/0000-0003-2432-4125

author: https://orcid.org/0000-0003-2432-4125

resp_text: An exact quote from the paper was added

author: https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0830-7029

author: https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0830-7029

author: https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0830-7029
text: The class 'cancer cell engaged in extracellular matrix' is defined as an intersection between 'extracellular matrix' and 'cancer cell'. But these two things are different, and cannot be formally intersected. instead, I might suggest that the subject type is a cancer cell that has a relation of 'located in' to an 'extracellular matrix'

author: https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0830-7029
text: The correct provenance here is a "FormalizationActivity", as the formalization was derived after such a specific activity. There the original article (https://www.nature.com/articles/nature13535) and the exact quote from the article that contained the scientific claim, together with the ORCID of the creator(s) should be specified.

author: https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0830-7029

author: https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0830-7029

author: https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0830-7029

author: https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0830-7029

author: https://orcid.org/0000-0002-7770-620X
text: The context class 'chemical to gene association' doesn't make sense to me here. I suppose we are talking about individual patients here, so then the context class 'human' would make sense, meaning whenever a human has this condition then it is sometimes related to that other condition *of the same human*.
resp_text: We discussed that and agreed to "universal context" together with a change of subject and object classes.

author: https://orcid.org/0000-0002-7770-620X
text: I am not sure about the isSameAs relation. This might be fine depending on how the other classes are filled in in the final version, but I have the impression that it should rather be something like isCausedBy.
resp_text: The publication is about overlapping genes in the disease networks of CAKUT and in the vitamin A targets. There is no causality involved.

author: https://orcid.org/0000-0002-7770-620X
text: The label of the superpattern instance should be a short human-readable sentence, not the DOI of the original paper.

author: https://orcid.org/0000-0002-7770-620X
text: The provenance part should use the template 'generated from a formalization activity'.

author: https://orcid.org/0000-0002-7770-620X
text: It seems to me that the object class should be something like 'excess or deficiency of vitamin A' and not just 'vitamin A'.
resp_text: No excess or deficiency involved here, that is just a statement that Vitamin A targets and CAKUT related proteins overlap (are sometimes the same).

author: https://orcid.org/0000-0002-7770-620X
text: I have some doubts about the context class used, as I am not sure if, from a biological point of view, the interpretation of the formalization makes sense.
resp_text: We discussed that and agree to change the context (and the classes) so that "universal context" fits best.

author: https://orcid.org/0000-0002-7770-620X
text: The provenance of this formalization is a specific type of provenance, namely, it is the result of a "formalization activity". This should be used in the provenance field with all the corresponding details pertaining to this "formalization activity". This is the place where the DOI of the article from which the quoted scientific claim was extracted should be specified.

author: https://orcid.org/0000-0002-7770-620X
text: If the formalization has multiple authors, then these need to be specified in this part, after choosing the "FormalizationActivity" as provenance of the formalization.
resp_text: Chris Evelo added as author as agreed.

author: https://orcid.org/0000-0002-7770-620X
text: The subject id http://identifiers.org/omim/610805 does not seem to resolve. Maybe using https://www.omim.org/entry/610805 is better?

author: https://orcid.org/0000-0002-7770-620X
text: The literal for the rdfs:label of the super-pattern instantiation should contain the actual (rephrased) scientific claim (ideally in an AIDA sentence), not the doi to the article. This should be changed.

author: https://orcid.org/0000-0002-8083-6048
text: Overall, I think this is a good formalization.
resp_text: Thank you! In response to your other review comment we made small changes to the formalisation.

author: https://orcid.org/0000-0003-2310-3013
text: With a protein class in the object position and a gene in the context, this raises for me the question what it means for a protein to be in the context of a gene. Maybe a class like 'presence of TAR DNA binding protein' in object position might make it clearer? But I am not sure...
resp_text: Whether we consider a protein in the context of a gene or the PRESENCE of the protein in that context is a subtle distinction whose need here eludes me. This requires further discussion.

author: https://orcid.org/0000-0001-9079-039X
text: I agree with this formalization.

author: https://orcid.org/0000-0001-9079-039X
text: I find the context class 'Digital Humanities' a bit confusing, as it is unclear to me what the instances of this class are. WikiData is not always very precise about this, but the superpattern is. I believe that a context class like 'Digital Humanities research' (as mentioned in the label) would make more sense.
resp_text:
I agree that this can be confusing. In response to a formalization review comment (3), I added a new class 
"Digital humanities research"which is a subclass of the resource "research" in wikidata and related to the resource "digital humanities" in wikidata.

author: https://orcid.org/0000-0001-9488-1870
text: Good formalization of an existing scientific paper with a wikipedia identifier. This also raises the question as to how publications should be referenced - e.g. by their DOI, pubmed, or indeed a wikipedia ID.
